stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: Prologue]
[Shadow Box: "Thou Shalt Not Suffer a Witch to Live" Exodus 22:18]

characterAction.tagContent: "Thou Shalt Not Suffer a Witch to Live." Exodus 22:18.
Did you know that when that verse was first translated into ancient Greek over two thousand years ago, it may have actually meant to warn against poisoners, not witches?
Nothing about magic and no mention at all about secret compacts with the Devil.
I wonder how those whose lives were irrevocably impacted by centuries of witch hunts and persecutions would react to that little piece of trivia.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Long beat as audience takes this in)
[Shadow Box: Out]

characterAction.tagContent: In fact, it wasn't until around the time the bible was first translated into English that the idea of witches as lost souls who convene with the Devil for nefarious means began to emerge.
Coincidence?

stgdContent.tagContent: (All three women shrug in their own way)

characterAction.tagContent: For centuries, witches have been scattered throughout the stories and histories of Western Civilization.
From fairy tales and plays of old, to even modern books and films, we've all grown up with an idea of what a witch may look like, or how she might behave.
Many of you right this very moment might even be thinking about another time you witnessed three seemingly innocent witches come together on a stage.
"Double, double toil and trouble; Fire burn and cauldron bubble!"

stgdContent.tagContent: (They laugh. Throughout the following, other witches enter and lurk in the shadows as lights slightly come up leaving them half visible in the background.)

characterAction.tagContent: But when our families first came over to America, there were no best selling children's books about family friendly witches.
You couldn't identify a witch by whether or not her skin was green.
And even the Brothers Grimm were still a couple of hundred years in the future.
When we first crossed the ocean and settled into our New England towns and villages, only one book made the journey.
The Bible.
And that book had a very clear stance on witches.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Shadow Box: "Thou Shalt Not Suffer a Witch to Live" Exodus 22:18]

characterAction.tagContent: "Thou Shalt Not Suffer a Witch to Live."

stgdContent.tagContent: (The TRIO stay in their pools of light as the rest of the lights go back out. Behind them during the following, multiple scenes are set in different parts of the stage by the others before they exit)
[Title Box: Out]
[Shadow Box: Out]

characterAction.tagContent: There was a dramatic cultural shift in the way suspected witches were accused and dealt with in the century between the European Witch Hunts and the events that took place across Salem in 1692.
Although tens of thousands of Europeans had been hanged or burned at the stake, the associated fear and hysteria had begun to fade by the time many made the long journey to the new colonies.
However, without having any solutions to the abundant threats they faced in the new world, many searched for guidance and advice in the superstitions of old.
And what better scapegoat than the Devil himself, or those working on his behalf, when your livestock dies overnight, or someone you care for comes down with a new and mysterious illness?

stgdContent.tagContent: (The pools of light fade out and NURSE, BISHOP, and MARTIN exit as lights come up on an empty stage as ELIZABETH HOWE and MARTHA CARRIER enter from opposite sides of the stage and meet in the middle. They turn to the audience)

sceneStructure.sceneDescription: BRIDGET BISHOP, SUSANNAH MARTIN, and REBECCA NURSE enter and cross downstage. As each "witch" enters, a pool of light comes up where they land, keeping the rest of the stage in darkness.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: The Afflicted Girls]

characterAction.tagContent: Towards the end of January, 1692, two young girls in Salem Village began to show signs of physical distress. For weeks, nine year old Betty Parris,
and her eleven year old cousin, Abigail Williams, would have frequent fits of convulsions and spasms, appearing to be in great pain.
However, these were not just any random girls. Both of these girls lived in the house of the newly ordained, and highly controversial, minister:

stgdContent.tagContent: (GILES COREY enters in time for:)

characterAction.tagContent: Samuel Parris.

stgdContent.tagContent: (G. COREY moves into the background. HOWE and CARRIER continue talking to the audience as they also get ready for the scene by laying down on benches and pulling blankets over themselves)

characterAction.tagContent: Many in Salem felt cheated by the rushed process in finding their new minister.
Unsure if he was the right fit, the village committee decided to vote against providing firewood for him and his family.
Leaving the Parris household to fend for themselves in the brutal New England winter, and causing Parris to resent the very community he was tasked with leading.
But the symptoms were getting worse for his daughter and niece, and he had to get to the bottom of it.

stgdContent.tagContent: (JOHN PROCTOR enters to G. COREY center stage)

characterAction.tagContent: And soon, a doctor was sent for, in order to weigh in on the mysterious illness.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Lights shift subtly to establish scene)

characterAction.tagContent: Do you have any idea what ails them, doctor?
Whatever it is, the only thing I can be certain of is that it is not natural in origin.
Doctor?
Reverend, I fear that the cause of the girls convulsions may well stem from some sort of... sorcery.
(Beat)
I believe them to be afflicted by witchcraft.

stgdContent.tagContent: (After a moment, J. PROCTOR exits to one side of the stage and takes off cloak as he settles into his scene. G. COREY crosses over to HOWE and CARRIER)

characterAction.tagContent: Do you see who does this to you?

stgdContent.tagContent: (Both girls shake their heads no)

characterAction.tagContent: I know not, father.

stgdContent.tagContent: (G. COREY places a damp piece of cloth on HOWE's head and then returns the background. MARTHA COREY enters to join J. PROCTOR. Across the stage, SARAH GOOD and ELIZABETH PROCTOR enter)

characterAction.tagContent: The fits of both young girls continued to grow worse, and before long, two more girls became afflicted.
The seventeen year old niece and housemaid of Dr. Griggs, Elizabeth Hubbard, who had likely heard about the afflictions from her guardian,
As well as twelve year old Ann Putnam Jr, the eldest child of Thomas Putnam and his wife-
Ann Putnam Sr. Both of whom were among the most prominent advocates for Reverend Parris and his parish.

stgdContent.tagContent: (HOWE, M. COREY, CARRIER, and GOOD all return to the scenes. All three scenes happen simultaneously)

characterAction.tagContent: Ann, please tell me who does this to you. Who hurts you and torments you with the devil's aide?
She blinds me with her magic.
Abigail, please. You need to give me a name. I cannot help you or my daughter if I do not know who is responsible.
She doesn't want me to know who she is.
She? So it is a witch?

stgdContent.tagContent: (ABIGAIL doesn't respond)

characterAction.tagContent: Elizabeth, I've always taken care of you since your parents passed, and I always will, but I need you to tell me now. Who afflicts you?
I can't tell, uncle. But she hurts me so. I feel her stabbing me with pins all over.
I've had enough of this, Betty. Now tell me: Whose face do you see when the fits come?

stgdContent.tagContent: (HOWE doesn't respond. J. PROCTOR, G. COREY, and E. PROCTOR all begin to leave. HOWE has one last spasm and faintly calls out:)

characterAction.tagContent: Tituba...

stgdContent.tagContent: (ALL stop moving. G. COREY turns to HOWE and rushes to her side. HOWE doesn't seem to realize what she said)

characterAction.tagContent: Tituba? Our Tituba does this to you? Is that who you see?

stgdContent.tagContent: (HOWE hesitantly nods her head)

characterAction.tagContent: ...yes.

stgdContent.tagContent: (G. COREY stands up and moves to leave before stopping once more)

characterAction.tagContent: Is there anyone else, Betty?
(Beat)
Does anyone else afflict you, or does the responsibility of these despicable actions rest solely on Tituba?
It's not only Tituba.
(Excitedly)
Who? Who else does this to you?

stgdContent.tagContent: (ALL AFFLICTED GIRLS turn to their guardians)

characterAction.tagContent: Sarah Good and Sarah Osborne.

stgdContent.tagContent: (G. COREY, J. PROCTOR, and E. PROCTOR all react to finally hearing names from their charges. Then they exit.)

characterAction.tagContent: To spare his daughter, he sent her to Salem Town to stay with a distant relative and to avoid what he knew was on the horizon.

stgdContent.tagContent: (HOWE exits)

characterAction.tagContent: As fear spread throughout the village, Samuel Parris began to notice that all of a sudden, the seats in his parish were filled, and there was no longer talk of trying to force him out.
However, if it had come out that Tituba, the reverend's own slave, was the sole cause of all of the sorcery, things would have changed quite quickly for the polarizing minister.

Fortunately for him, his daughter and niece, as well as the other two afflicted girls, all soon named the other two women, officially kicking off what would become the foundation for the Salem Witch Trials with three accused witches.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Lights out as GOOD, M. COREY, and CARRIER exit. A pool of light comes up downstage and SUSANNAH MARTIN walks into it)
[Title Box: Salem's First Three Witches]
[Shadow Box: Salem Village Meetinghouse]

characterAction.tagContent: Following the accusations from the afflicted girls, warrants went out for Tituba, Sarah Good, and Sarah Osborne, and the very next day all three were held for questioning by the local magistrates. Sarah Good, a local homeless woman who was known for wandering door to door with her four year old daughter Dorothy begging for food or shelter, was often seen muttering under her breath when leaving, regardless of the outcome, which led many to believe she was casting spells. During her examination, she claimed innocence, and when the girls in the crowd began to act tormented, she blamed her co-accused Sarah Osborne. Osborne, on the other hand, maintained that she had nothing to do with witchcraft and was confused as to why anyone would claim otherwise. However, one family in Salem Village would disagree with that notion. A few years prior when her husband passed away, he left the land to their two sons. But when she eventually remarried, she kept the land for herself, which greatly angered her late husband's relatives... the Putnam family. But the one who stood out the most out of the trio, was Samuel Parris' slave Tituba. She was liked within the minister's household, and unlike the Sarahs who were named alongside her, the community in general knew very little about her. Although before very long, that would all change. When Tituba was examined in front of a crowd nearly the size of the village itself, she not only admitted to hurting the girls and being a witch, but she swore that both Sarah Good and Sarah Osborne, as well as a few others whose names she did not know, were all tormenting the girls

Magistrates Hathorne and Corwin decided they had enough evidence to charge the three women with witchcraft, and they were all sent to Boston to wait in jail for their trials while the rest of Salem Village began to wonder to themselves just who those other witches she talked about might be.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: Out]
[Shadow Box: Out]

(The pool of light goes out as MARTIN exits. Lights transition into two scenes in the background. On one side of the stage, MARTHA COREY and GILES COREY enter and sit on chairs facing each other. On the other side of the stage, ELIZABETH PROCTOR, SARAH GOOD, and ELIZABETH HOWE enter and huddle around a table)

sceneStructure.sceneDescription: Throughout the following, shadow puppets appear and act out the scenes as they are narrated.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: Martha Corey, The Oracle]

characterAction.tagContent: The Putnams were not the type to let such an enticing opportunity simply pass them by.
But this was quickly becoming far too important of an operation to place in the hands of just one twelve year old girl,
So they also recruited their orphaned maid Mercy Lewis to assist them.
And with the community fearful of who else might be working with the devil,

stgdContent.tagContent: (JOHN PROCTOR enters and joins the Putnam side)

characterAction.tagContent: Thomas Putnam and his family went to work.
It was a good time to be on the side of the Putnams.
Something I wish my wife Martha would have considered before publicly declaring the afflicted to be a bunch of foolish girls starving for attention.
(to G. COREY)
Hush, Giles. What are you even doing over here? You're supposed to be over there playing Ezekiel Cheever so you can verify what the Putnams say happened.
Oh! That's this scene?

stgdContent.tagContent: (M. COREY sighs deeply in frustration. J. PROCTOR, E. PROCTOR, GOOD, and HOWE attempt to quietly signal for G. COREY to get over to their side. M. COREY gives G. COREY a slight push, and he finally crosses over to the Putnam side. ALL transition into their scenes. M. COREY is busy folding linens on her side, while the rest begin on the other side. Lights dim on Corey side)

characterAction.tagContent: We will be going over to the Corey household shortly to inquire about her actions.
When she attacked you this morning, can you remember what it was that she was wearing? If she is wearing the same when we call upon her, it will prove her guilt.

I could not tell. When she first came to me, she blinded me so that I could not see her or what she was wearing, but she told me her name. She told me it was Goody Corey and that she'd be back to hurt me again!

stgdContent.tagContent: (J. PROCTOR and G. COREY exit the Putnam side of the stage and make their way to the Corey side. Lights dim on the Putnams, and rise on the Coreys. J. PROCTOR and G. COREY walk up behind M. COREY. He takes off his hat and starts to talk)

characterAction.tagContent: I am not a witch.
Uh.. E-excuse me?

stgdContent.tagContent: (M. COREY turns to face J. PROCTOR directly now)

characterAction.tagContent: That is why you are here, is it not? To accuse me of being a witch like those three poor women you all paraded through the village last week?
Those, women, were conspiring with the devil to torment my daughter. As well as the daughter and niece of our minister, I might add.

stgdContent.tagContent: (M. COREY scoffs and returns to folding her linens)

characterAction.tagContent: The only thing afflicting those young girls is a bad case of wanting to get out of their housework. You and I both know that.
Are you saying that my daughter is lying, Goody Corey?
Aye.
I assure you tha-
Oh drop the act, Thomas. We both know that you don't have any evidence to formally make an accusation because no such evidence exists.
(Sternly)
There are other ways of determining guilt.
Are there now?
(Pausing her folding)
Okay, then. If I have been attacking your daughter as you suggest, what is it that I was wearing when she saw me? I doubt she could answer such a question.

stgdContent.tagContent: (M. COREY turns back to her work with a smug smile on her face. G. COREY and J. PROCTOR look shocked)

characterAction.tagContent: Excuse me, Goody Corey, but why would you ask such a question?

Because if she could tell you what I was wearing all the way back at the Putnam farm, then you would know that I had been there. But since I highly doubt she could know such a thing, I am not worried.
You should be, Goody Corey.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Annoyed, M. COREY stares up at the two men)

characterAction.tagContent: And why is that?
Because young Ann did say you came to her this very morning.
And she said that you knew we'd ask what you were wearing, so you blinded her!
Then how did she know it was I?
She said you told her so.
Goodman Putnam, if you think me a witch, then you are the blind one. The eyes of all those in Salem who think so are kept closed. But I will open them.

stgdContent.tagContent: (M. COREY returns to her work once more. J. PROCTOR and G. COREY share a look, and then leave the Corey side. Lights fade and scene resets. ALL reset the stage and exit as a pool of light comes up downstage and REBECCA NURSE enters into it)
[Title Box: Don't Mess with the Putnams]
[Shadow Box: Putnam Household]

characterAction.tagContent: With Martha Corey, two other names were supplied by the Putnam family that week. Dorothy Good, the four year old daughter of now imprisoned Sarah, was questioned and then arrested when Ann Jr and Mary Walcott claimed that she acted like a deranged animal, and that her apparition would bite and scratch them. And soon, news would reach me at my home that another name provided by the Putnam clan was none other than my own, Rebecca Nurse. The most absurd part of it all, is that no one even knows who it was who first mentioned my name. Ann Putnam Jr and Mercy Lewis both claimed that it was Ann's mother who told them to accuse me. Whereas Ann Sr told everyone that her daughter had provided my name. Despite the confusion about how I was initially accused, more would join in and claim that I was afflicting them. I never stood a chance.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Shadow Box: Proctor Household]

However, as more and more girls throughout the village became afflicted, not everyone in the community was so quick to believe their stories. John Proctor, a local farmer whose own maid had begun to have fits, was heard telling his neighbor that he thought that the girls should all be hanged for the lies they were spreading.

characterAction.tagContent: Word of what John Proctor had said about the girls quickly made it back to the families of the afflicted, and by the end of the week, his wife Elizabeth Proctor, was brought in for questioning.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: Out]
[Shadow Box: Out]

(The pool of light goes out as NURSE exits. GILES COREY enters and crosses to the judge's bench. MARTHA CARRIER, SARAH GOOD, ELIZABETH HOWE, SARAH WILDES, MARTHA COREY, ALICE PARKER, and MARY EASTY enter and cross to the witness benches. JOHN PROCTOR enters and sits in front of them. ELIZABETH PROCTOR enters last and crosses up to the examination chair as the lights settle in for the court setting)

sceneStructure.sceneDescription: Throughout the following, shadow puppets appear and act out the scenes as they are narrated.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: The Examination of Elizabeth Proctor]

characterAction.tagContent: (to Afflicted Girls)
Is this the woman who torments you?
She tried to make me sign her book!
Me too! She showed me her dark book and told me to sign it or she'd have my life.

stgdContent.tagContent: (GOOD stands and moves to strike E. PROCTOR but before she can hit her, she howls in pain and falls to the floor)

characterAction.tagContent: Look up on the beam, her spirit sits and mocks us!

stgdContent.tagContent: (CARRIER points to the ceiling and everyone follows her gaze)

characterAction.tagContent: This is pure nonsense, Magistr-
Oh no, Goodman Proctor is about to make Mercy Lewis have a fit!

stgdContent.tagContent: (HOWE hears this and then has a fit)

characterAction.tagContent: Look how he makes Elizabeth Hubbard levitate!

stgdContent.tagContent: (M. COREY lifts in her seat, but before anyone can investigate, G. COREY continues)

characterAction.tagContent: (to J. PROCTOR)
What do you say to this?
I-
Watch out! He plans to attack Susanna Sheldon and Betty Booth!

stgdContent.tagContent: (PARKER and EASTY writhe in pain)

characterAction.tagContent: Do you see how the Devil will deceive you?
Now he is to make us all fall over.

stgdContent.tagContent: (ALL the afflicted girls fall over in unison)

characterAction.tagContent: The children could see what you were going to do before you hurt them!
This is Nonsense!

stgdContent.tagContent: (ALL except J. PROCTOR freeze. He turns to the audience, visibly shaken from the chaos)

characterAction.tagContent: By the end of the day my wife and I were in chains and on our way to the Boston jail, and I was officially the first man accused of witchcraft in Salem Village.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Lights fade as ALL exit. Three pools of light appear downstage as SUSANNAH MARTIN, BRIDGET BISHOP, and REBECCA NURSE enter into them)
[Title Box: The Power of the Afflicted]

characterAction.tagContent: After the events that occurred during the examination of Elizabeth Proctor, the group of girls headed by Ann Putnam Jr and Abigail Williams became known as the "Visionary Girls".
And by the first couple weeks of May, these visionary girls went on to accuse dozens more throughout Salem and beyond.
Nearby towns and villages had started hearing all about the witches of Salem, and the brave young girls who stood up to them.
So whenever someone was taken ill without any known origin, witchcraft was quickly assumed to be the cause.
The reputation of the visionary girls led the leaders of neighboring communities to send word, asking if they would come visit and lend their talents to root out witches.
And by using local gossip, town history, and the reputations of those who lived nearby, names were quickly provided.
And so while more people were still being questioned and imprisoned in Salem Village, other communities quickly joined in by sending their own accused to Boston in order to await trial.
The vast majority of all the people who were rounded up over the next few weeks fit into one of three categories.
Some were easy targets who simply had a history of being stubborn or difficult-
As was the case for both Susannah Martin and Bridget Bishop here. (MARTIN and BISHOP glare at NURSE) as well as Martha Carrier:
A year or so before the visionary girls came to Andover, my family had moved to town. Shortly after, we all came down with Smallpox, which some in the community claimed we brought.
and of course Sarah Good:
Who better to lock up than the local homeless woman who was a constant thorn in everyone's side
Others were targeted for their decisions to speak out against the proceedings like the Proctors and the Corey's had,
They targeted my wife Elizabeth for calling them Liars.
And then John for defending me in court.
I warned Martha not to dismiss the girls so quickly.
Yet my fool of a husband Giles went and did the same thing after I was arrested.
And as John Willard was about to do
It was my job to arrest the accused, but I saw through their lies and refused to be their muscle any longer.
Whereas others found themselves guilty of perhaps the most scandalous offense of all... Standing in the way of the Putnam family. A lesson Rebecca Nurse had to learn the hard way:

I had never done a single thing to the Putnam family. But they had been in power struggles with my husband, as well as land battles with my brothers. Yet it was the women in my family who paid the price.
(Beat)
Soon after my arrest, two of my sister's were also accused. My sister Mary Easty-

Would be tried and found guilty less than a month after Rebecca. Our other sister Sarah Cloyce was also jailed, but she would eventually live to see the end of the trials. The Putnams didn't stop with just us though. They even went after another relation: Elizabeth Howe.

I had been in the middle of my own land dispute against a neighboring family when their daughter became ill. Soon after, I was accused of witchcraft since it was believed to run in families, even though I was only the niece by law of Rebecca, Mary, and Sarah.
And then there was the wicked Sarah Wildes:
My biggest mistake was marrying a man just seven months after his wife had died. His late wife... a member of the Putnams.
One by one the outcasts, the brave, and the enemies of those in power were accused, examined, and sent to jail..
It was during this time that the first victim of the Salem Witch trials lost their life. Sarah Osborne, one of the original three to be accused, died in prison while awaiting trial.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: The Search for John Willard]
[Shadow Box: Willard Household]

characterAction.tagContent: At about the same time that the innocent prisoners witnessed the first death from their group, scared villagers believed they witnessed the first murder by a witch against a victim. John Willard had been a constable tasked with the job of bringing in accused witches for examinations. As he saw how the young girls behaved, however, he stepped away from his job, refusing to contribute to what he saw as frivolous accusations. To perhaps nobody's surprise but his own, the afflicted girls soon went on to then accuse him of being a witch. Wanting to avoid the ordeal, Willard decided to go on the run. But the idea of a witch on the loose heightened an already tense community, and even with him gone, the girls found ways to cause him trouble. When Willard's cousin-in-law Daniel Wilkins became suddenly sick, the girls seized the opportunity to blame him for that as well. Mercy Lewis claimed to see Willard's apparition hovering over and afflicting him. She then made the bold prediction that if Willard was not apprehended within the next two days, that Wilkins would die from his afflictions. Unfortunately, for both Wilkins and Willard, Mercy's bluff proved to be true and two days later, Wilkins passed away. A new warrant was released for Willard's arrest, and two days later they discovered him hiding out halfway across the colony, tending to one of his properties. He was immediately examined and sent to prison for the murder of Daniel Wilkins.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Shadow Box: Out]

sceneStructure.sceneDescription: Throughout the following, shadow puppets appear and act out the scenes as they are narrated.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: The Court of Oyer and Terminer]

characterAction.tagContent: As the newly appointed Governor began to assemble a panel of judges to oversee the witch trials, there was one topic no one could seem to agree on:
The issue of whether or not to allow testimony including supernatural evidence into the trials.
But the magistrates and residents of Salem and throughout the colony had already put a lot of weight on the testimony of those who claimed to have visions or see apparitions.
And to ignore it entirely would have led to most of the cases being dismissed before the trials even started.
Which was not really a great strategy for a group of judges trying to make a name for themselves in a new world.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Beat)

characterAction.tagContent: In the end, they decided to hear all potential evidence against the accused,
And the Court of Oyer and Terminer wasted no time in going after their first victim.
It couldn't be one of the first accused, since Sarah Osborne had already died in prison, and Sarah Good was about to give birth to a new baby any day.
And Tituba was thought to be a prime witness for many of the cases, so they couldn't start with her either.
Instead they decided to go with someone they knew beyond any reasonable doubt that they could make the accusation stick.
Someone who had been accused of being a witch before.
Someone with other crimes on their record other than just witchcraft.
Someone they knew absolutely no one could argue was anything but the vilest...
Most treacherous...
Good for noth-
That's enough!

stgdContent.tagContent: (Lights out on NURSE and MARTIN. BISHOP is all alone on stage. MARTIN and NURSE move to sit in the back of the witness benches as GILES COREY enters and crosses to the judge's bench. MARTHA CARRIER, SARAH GOOD, ELIZABETH HOWE, SARAH WILDES, MARTHA COREY, ALICE PARKER, and MARY EASTY enter and cross to the witness benches)

sceneStructure.sceneTitle: 8. The Court of Oyer and Terminer

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: The Trial of Bridget Bishop]

characterAction.tagContent: Bridget Bishop, You are now brought before Authority to give account of what witchcraft you have conversed in.
(to Afflicted Girls)
Has this woman hurt you?
She has!
Goody Bishop pokes me with pins and stabs me!
She stabs me as well!
You are accused by many for hurting them, what do you say to it?
I never saw these persons before; nor I never was in this place before.
My brother struck at her appearance when she came to me, and we heard her coat tear!

stgdContent.tagContent: (HATHORNE motions for BISHOP to show her cloak, and indeed a tear can be seen in it)

characterAction.tagContent: They say you bewitched your first husband to death.
If it please your worship, I know nothing of it.

stgdContent.tagContent: (BISHOP shakes her head, and the afflicted girls all writhe in pain as their heads shake too)

characterAction.tagContent: It's been said that you have been called a witch for over 10 years, but that you don't think you are a witch because the Devil can't hurt you.
I am no witch. I have no familiarity with the Devil.
How is it then, that your appearance hurts these girls?
I am innocent.
Then why do we witness witchcraft before us. The way you move your body impacts the afflicted before our eyes.
I know nothing of it. I am not a witch. I don't know what a witch is.
How do you know that you are not a witch if you do not know what one is?
Let me be clear. If I were any such person, you would know it.
You may threaten me, but that is all you can do here.
I told you, I am innocent.
(Lights shift to downstage pools. BISHOP walks into one as MARTIN and NURSE join her)
I was the only one tried and executed in that first session. I was an example. A threat. An omen of things to come. But I wouldn't be there for any of it.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Beat. BISHOP exits as NURSE and MARTIN watch her go)

sceneStructure.sceneDescription: Lights shift to the courtroom. As BISHOP crosses to the examination chair, the afflicted girls fall into fits.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: The First Execution]

characterAction.tagContent: Everything changed after Bridget.
The community began to split between those wanting the trials to end, and those who wanted to root out all the perceived evils in Salem and beyond.
And things had only gotten worse by the time I was pulled in...

stgdContent.tagContent: (Everyone changes seats. NURSE returns to the upstage bench. MARTIN moves to sit in the examination chair)

sceneStructure.sceneDescription: NURSE and MARTIN glance at the empty light solemnly, and then return to the audience.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: The Trial of Susannah Martin]

characterAction.tagContent: (to Afflicted Girls)
Do you know this Woman?
Aye! It is Goody Martin. She hath hurt me often.

stgdContent.tagContent: (GOOD throws her glove at MARTIN in a fit. MARTIN laughs loudly)

characterAction.tagContent: What, do you laugh at it?
Well I may at such folly.
Is this folly? The hurt of these young girls?
(Scoffing)
I never hurt man, woman, or child.
She hath hurt me a great many times as well, and she pulls me down!

stgdContent.tagContent: (MARTIN laughs again)

characterAction.tagContent: This woman hath hurt me a great many times!
What do you say to all this?
I have no hand in witchcraft.
What did you do then? Did you not give yourself to the Devil?
No, never in my life.
Then what ails these girls?
I do not know.
But what do you think?
I have no interest in thinking of such things.
So you do not think they are bewitched?
No.
(Beat)
I do not think they are.

stgdContent.tagContent: (AFFLICTED GIRLS moan and scream. They all react differently, but obviously distressed)

characterAction.tagContent: Then tell me your thoughts about them.
I cannot give you my thoughts, for they are only mine when I possess them. If I gave my thoughts, then they would belong to you.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Long Beat Lights shift. Everyone except MARTIN and NURSE freezes.)

characterAction.tagContent: (to audience) I don't think they liked how I handled the early examination, and I was thrown in jail shortly following that encounter. However, if I thought that by the time I was called for trial they would use more sense, I was sorely mistaken. Behold the undeniable evidence placed upon me...

stgdContent.tagContent: (Lights return. Everyone changes seats to imply it is a different time. ELIZABETH PROCTOR and JOHN PROCTOR enter separately. J. PROCTOR stands in front of the benches as E. PROCTOR sits)

characterAction.tagContent: Goody Atkinson, what say you about Goody Martin?

Eighteen years hence, I was visited upon by Goody Martin. She had walked all the way from her home in Amesbury to my own, nine miles away in Newbury. It was a particularly dirty and wet time of year, but when she arrived at my door...
(Beat)
she was as dry and clean as I was.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Murmurs increase)

characterAction.tagContent: Goody Martin, how do you explain walking nine miles in such conditions, and yet be as clean as if you had just stepped out your own door.
(Incredulously)
I do not enjoy a dirty cloak. Have you ever attempted to get mud and soil out of clean linen?

stgdContent.tagContent: (Murmurs continue to grow as no one listens to her. Lights shift. ALL are still as MARTIN and NURSE walk down to their pools of light. MARTIN is silent, and then exits)

characterAction.tagContent: Susannah was found guilty of witchcraft that morning and sentenced to hang. However, unlike Bridget Bishop, she would not do so alone.

stgdContent.tagContent: (NURSE moves to sit in the examination chair. G. COREY stays at the judge's bench. HOWE exits. CARRIER, GOOD, WILDES, M. COREY, PARKER, and EASTY reposition. E. PROCTOR sits close to WILDES. J. PROCTOR exits)
[Title Box: The Trial of Rebecca Nurse]

characterAction.tagContent: Is this the woman you have seen?
I have seen her, but I do not know if she is the one who has hurt me.
She has hurt me! She has bitten and pinched me.
And I as well. She sits in my grandmother's chair and mocks and torments me.
What say you, Goody Nurse?
The lord knows I have not hurt them. I am an innocent person.

stgdContent.tagContent: (WILDES screams and holds her arm close to her body while displaying three pins for all to see)

characterAction.tagContent: Rebecca Nurse just appeared before me and stuck me with these pins!

stgdContent.tagContent: (E. PROCTOR stands up)

characterAction.tagContent: She lies! I just saw her pull those pins from her dress with my own eyes.
She stood in front of me and told me it was her and not the devil. It is her who hurts me!
I am as innocent as a newborn and have hurt no one!
Yet they accuse you of hurting them, so if you think they are untruthful, then you must look upon them as murders.
I do think them bewitched, but I cannot help if the devil appears in my image.
(Lights shift. Everyone except NURSE freezes)
(to audience)

No matter how I responded, Judge Hathorne refused to believe me, and he sent me to jail to await my trial. Thirty-nine brave villagers, including cousins and relatives of Thomas Putnam, signed a petition asking for my release, but it had no effect. Instead I was kept locked up in conditions unsuitable for someone of my age and health for almost a hundred days before my trial.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Lights return. Everyone changes seats to imply it is a different time. ELIZABETH HOWE enters downstage)

characterAction.tagContent: How does the jury find the prisoner?
We the jury find Rebecca Nurse... Not Guilty.

stgdContent.tagContent: (There is a general uproar in the crowd. Some are happy, others are furious. The noise is overwhelming)

characterAction.tagContent: Quiet! All of you. Sit in your seats and remain quiet. (to HOWE) Did you say Not Guilty?
I did.

stgdContent.tagContent: (G. COREY considers this for a moment)

characterAction.tagContent: Did the jury consider the testimony given in which the accused referred to Goody Hobbs, a confessed witch, in saying "I thought she was one of us?"
If it pleases the honored court, we did.
I think you should all take some time to consider it once more.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Lights dim. A pool of light remains over NURSE)

characterAction.tagContent: (to audience)
The jury reconvened to discuss the matter before coming back to ask me a question.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Lights reset to courtroom)

characterAction.tagContent: Has the jury re-considered the testimony?
We'd like to ask Goody Nurse a question if we may?
Proceed.
Goody Nurse. We'd like to know what it is you meant when you referred to the known witch, Goody Hobbs, as "one of us". Can you explain this to us?

stgdContent.tagContent: (NURSE is not looking at HOWE at all. She is just staring off into the distance and ignoring everything in sight. Lights dim. A pool of light remains over NURSE)

characterAction.tagContent: (to audience)

What no one told them, or that they failed to notice throughout my entire trial, was that at the age of 72, I had lost most of my hearing. I didn't even know that anyone had asked me a question until two days later when my family came to visit me and asked me about it. I thought we were all just waiting.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Lights reset to courtroom)

characterAction.tagContent: Has the jury finally reached a verdict?

We have. Although we had originally found Rebecca Nurse Not Guilty of witchcraft, the evidence that the honored courtroom encouraged us to review, along with the unsatisfactory response from Goody Nurse when questioned, has led us to re-consider our decision. We, the jury of Essex County find Rebecca Nurse Guilty on all charges of witchcraft.

stgdContent.tagContent: (CROWD erupts again, this time with opposite reactions from each faction until lights switch to display three pools of light downstage. ALL exit as NURSE walks into her pool of light. The other two remain empty. She looks out to the audience, and after a beat, exits. Lights out.)
[Title Box: John Proctor's Letter to Boston]

characterAction.tagContent: ...having condemned us already before our trials, being so much incensed and engaged against us by the Devil, makes us bold to beg and implore your...
(J. PROCTOR pauses and looks out to the audience)
(to audience)
Oh.
(Beat)
Um.
(Beat)
I apologize for that. You were probably expecting one of them
(Gesturing to TRIO offstage)

to keep this whole thing going, but... well... the truth is that we've reached the end of their stories.On July 19th, 1692, Susannah Martin and Rebecca Nurse, were hanged in Salem Village. Along side them were, Elizabeth Howe, Sarah Wildes, and Sarah Good, whose newborn daughter had also passed a few days after entering the world in a Boston jail cell. At this point in the historic events of Salem, less than a third of the total executions had yet to take place. But the seed of doubt that Bridget's politically sanctioned murder had planted quickly grew into public indignation by the way Rebecca Nurse had been treated. With nearly two hundred people imprisoned, and a flawless conviction record of six for six, the Court of Oyer and Terminer plowed ahead without hesitation.

stgdContent.tagContent: (J. PROCTOR has hit his pool of light by this point. Lights shift)

sceneStructure.sceneDescription:
Lights up on JOHN PROCTOR sitting on the floor as he writes a letter in dim light. He reads what he is writing as he puts the quill to paper.

Throughout the scene, he makes his way downstage left towards a slowly growing pool of light.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: George Corwin, The High Sheriff of Essex County]
[Shadow Box: Proctor Household]

characterAction.tagContent: In addition to the way we were treated in the jail and courtroom, I had also recently discovered that Sheriff George Corwin, the favorite nephew of Judge Corwin, had ransacked my entire estate. He went about and stole anything that was not attached to the property. Even going as far as dumping out all of our food, ale, and supplies that he could not take with him just so that my family couldn't use them. My eleven children were left with a home empty of food or firewood.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Shadow Box: Salem Jail]

I had also learned that my son, as well as the family members of Martha Carrier, had been tortured by the Sheriff in an attempt to elicit a guilty plea. Only when a man who was more merciful than the rest took pity upon was my son, was he released and sent home with marks all over his body and blood dripping from his nose. In a desperate attempt for mercy, I wrote a letter to a number of influential ministers from Boston, begging for them to send help, or at the very least for them to attend the trials so that some sort of justice could be restored.No reply ever came, so the trials and executions continued as planned. Within the next couple of weeks, six more innocent souls, including myself, my wife Elizabeth, Martha Carrier, George Jacobs Sr, John Willard, and George Burroughs would be condemned to be hanged, effectively doubling the total number of victims.
[Shadow Box: Out]
(ELIZABETH PROCTOR enters and walks over to J. PROCTOR. She places her hand on his shoulder before turning to the audience)

sceneStructure.sceneTitle: 14. George Corwin, The High Sheriff of Essex County
sceneStructure.sceneDescription: Throughout the following, shadow puppets appear and act out the scenes as they are narrated.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: A Life Spared]

characterAction.tagContent: Despite being found guilty, I was given a temporary reprieve due to the fact I was pregnant. The rest of my group, including my husband, weren't so lucky.
(J. PROCTOR looks up to E. PROCTOR. They share a look before he exits)

By this point in the trials, most of the community seemed split on how to proceed. Serious doubts had been raised about the way things were being handled, yet many were afraid to speak up about their concerns out of fear of being accused themselves. Letters from throughout the colony were sent to the Governor pleading with him to intercede, but they continued to go unanswered as those who were currently in charge of the trials continued to feel empowered by their successes and began to seem invincible.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: The Pressing of Giles Corey]
[Shadow Box: Salem Village Meetinghouse]

characterAction.tagContent: The next to feel the brunt of their wrath was Giles Corey. Finally, after spending over 150 days in prison, he was finally given his day in court. After seeing how his wife had been treated during her trial, Giles had no interest in participating in what he had come to believe was a mockery of justice. So when the judges proceeded to ask if he would accept the terms of the trial, Giles refused to respond. The court was at a loss. Their own tradition stated that without his consent, they could not proceed with a trial. However, Thomas Putnam stepped up and reminded the court of an old English law which outlined a method for dealing with such a situation. The technique included laying an individual down on the ground before placing a wooden plank across the length of their body. Then they would add one stone after another, stopping only to ask the victim if they were willing to give their consent. Giles Corey, at the age of 81, withstood this torture for hours. When asked once more if he was willing to stand trial, he had two words for Sheriff Corwin: More Weight.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Beat)
[Shadow Box: Out]
(Lights shift back to a single pool of light above E. PROCTOR)

sceneStructure.sceneDescription: Throughout the following, shadow puppets appear and act out the scenes as they are narrated.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: The Final Trip to Gallows Hill]

characterAction.tagContent: News of the torture of Giles Corey sent shockwaves throughout the village, but another group, including his own wife Martha, were already set to be executed just two days later. On September 22nd, 1692, eight more victims of the witch-hunt, Mary Easty, Martha Corey, Ann Pudeator, Samuel Wardwell, Mary Parker, Alice Parker, Wilmot Redd and Margaret Scott were driven out to Gallows Hill and executed in front of Salem village. With eight new names added to the books, it was the deadliest day of the Salem Witch Trials. But perhaps the most surprising victim of that fateful afternoon was the Court of Oyer and Terminer itself.
(Lights shift as E. PROCTOR crosses towards mid stage. The rest of the ensemble returns to the stage a few moments before their line)
As more and more complaints of disgust made their way to those in Boston, someone finally decided to take a stand.
One week later, Governor Phips orders that supernatural evidence would no longer allowed,
Effectively rendering most of the accusations against the over 150 people still waiting in jail useless.
And by the end of October, Phips put a stop to any further arrests of suspected witches throughout the colonies
Despite this limitation, the new court still managed to find three more woman guilty of witchcraft,
and in January, Chief Justice Stoughton signed the death warrant for the newly condemned,
as well as those such as Elizabeth Proctor who were previously sentenced but still waiting their execution.
Finally, almost a full year after the first warrant was issued for three innocent women in the small village of Salem, all that had been accused were finally released.
In a tragic case of symmetry, the last person released from jail was the same who kicked off the entire hysteria.
Tituba had previously renounced her claims about witchcraft and later admitted that Parris told her that he would leave her to rot in jail if she didn't keep the lies going.
A promise that he would keep. She was eventually sold to an unknown family who agreed to pay for her court fees after Parris refused to do so a year later.
(Beat)

Accusers and accused alike would spend decades living in the same communities as each other, attending the same churches, and voting on the same committees, all without anyone officially taking responsibility for what had happened.
All except one young woman.
Almost two decades after the events of Salem, Ann Putnam Jr decided to break the silence on what had occurred, offering an apology for her part in the events.
She was the only afflicted to ever do so.

sceneStructure.sceneTitle: 17. The Final Trip to Gallows Hill

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: The Apology of Ann Putnam Jr]

characterAction.tagContent: "I, Ann Putnam, desire to be humbled before God for that sad and humbling providence that befell my father's family in the year about '92; that I, then being in my childhood, should, by such a providence of God, be made an instrument for the accusing of several persons of a grievous crime, whereby their lives were taken away from them, whom now I have just grounds and good reason to believe they were innocent persons..."

stgdContent.tagContent: (Lights shift)

sceneStructure.sceneTitle: 18. The Apology of Ann Putnam Jr
sceneStructure.sceneDescription:
SARAH GOOD enters into a downstage pool of light, as ALL enter and watch from their places on stage.

She is holding a letter in her hand, and she occasionally glances at it as she reads it out loud for everyone to hear.

stgdContent.tagContent: [Title Box: Finale]

characterAction.tagContent: "Innocent persons."

stgdContent.tagContent: (Beat)

characterAction.tagContent: Those innocent persons were Sarah Osborne, Roger Toothaker,
Bridget Bishop,
Sarah and Mercy Good,
Rebecca Nurse,
Susannah Martin,
Sarah Wildes,
Elizabeth Howe,
John Proctor,
Martha Carrier,
John Willard,
George Jacobs Sr, George Burroughs
Giles Corey,
Martha Corey,
Mary Easty.
Alice Parker, Ann Pudeator, Margaret Scott,
Wilmot Redd, Samuel Wardwell, Mary Parker,
Ann Foster, and Lydia Dustin.
Twenty Five "innocent persons" would lose their lives in a nine month time period.
Nineteen were hanged at the gallows.
Four were left to die in a jail cell that they never belonged in.

And two were tortured to death all in an attempt to extract the guilt for a crime that was fabricated for no reason other than a failed attempt to grab power for those who felt wronged by their community in the past. Power that was never obtained.
Only time would eventually allow our loved ones to continue forward where we could not, and even perhaps learn how to forgive those who had wronged us.

stgdContent.tagContent: (Lights shift. GOOD continues reading from her letter. Throughout the following, the group moves in close behind her, some placing their hands gently on her shoulder, as they dip their heads)

characterAction.tagContent: ..I was a cause, with others, of so sad a calamity to them and their families; for which cause I desire to lie in the dust, and earnestly beg forgiveness of God, and from all those unto whom I have given just cause of sorrow and offense."
END OF ACT

sceneStructure.sceneDescription: ALL enter into their spots just before their lines, looking out to the audience.
